name: Hannah K
comment info: Researchers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have collected data on the consumption of tobacco products by middle school and high school students from 2011-2018. This information is displayed in the graph to the left, and there are two distinct lines per age group, one regarding tobacco products at large, and the other specifically concerning e-cigarettes. I notice that while the use of any tobacco products has increased for middle schoolers in 2017 from roughly 4% to 7% of students, the use of any tobacco products for high schoolers has significantly jumped in 2017 from about 19% to about 27% of students. I see that the line describing the use of exclusively e-cigarettes is identical to the upward trend of the line depicting the use of any tobacco product, which makes me thinks that e-cigarettes are the major contributor to the growth in consumption over the past seven years. Perhaps this is the obvious question, but I wonder why this is? I have a hard time coming to any solid answer to this question. Also, what could the government do to deter the continuation of this pattern? A month ago, I heard in the news that the FDA is working on banning popular flavors of pods for Juuls, a very popular e-cigarette brand, that students might find appealing, such as mango and mint. How else could the government aid this situation? Is the federal government’s intervention constitutional?

name: Ethan Hoang
comment info: I notice that this graph is around 2011-2013 and that middle and high school students is starting to smoke and that it goes up to 2013-2015 and then goes down to 2015-2017 and now it is going up in 2018-present day. They were smoking a lot of tobacco, but not a lot of vaping and e-cigarettes. The middle school students did less of that than high school students. The graph is going neutral to up then down then up. I wonder why middle school students smoke less tobacco than high school students. I wonder why middle and high school students are smoking and that they try to harm their body. I wonder how they get all of these drugs and why would they use it for. I wonder if they’re using it to impress other people or that they think they’re cool when they’re smoking. The story this graph is telling us is that high school students smoking a lot of tobacco than middle school students. “High School Students Likes Smoking a lot of Tobacco than Middle School Students!”

name: Madison S.
comment info: This graph shows the percentages of both middle school students  and high school students who have tried e-cigarettes and then also the statistics for the use of any tobacco products. In 2011 E-cigarettes were not very popular in either group of students. For both high school and middle school students, the percentages began to increase at a greater rate until 2015. The next large increase came in 2017- most likely a result of the release of the juul E-cigarette. This product was originally marketed as a "cool item" and its advertisements included young adults, even though it was intended to be a device to help adult smokers eventually quit. The advertisements have since been changed, but the original affect on teens and tweens could not be reversed. Overall, the use of E-cigarettes has increased dramatically accounting for about half the percentage as any tobacco product. A good headline for this graph would be "Coughing Out Too Big a Cloud of Smoke"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Madison S. --
To give perspective using counts instead of percentages, according to the U. S. Center for Disease Control, the number of middle and high school students using e-cigarettes rose from 2.1 million in 2017 to 3.6 million in 2018 – a difference of 1.5 million – a 71 percent increase.  You can go to the CDC report on Youth and Tobacco Use (https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/data_statistics/fact_sheets/youth_data/tobacco_use/index.htm) to read more about how tobacco consumption is changing drastically.
What’s happening here?  Why do we care?  What could be done about this?

My grade 7 class had some questions:

1. How are middle school kids getting e-cigarettes?
2.Why did both "any tobacco product" and e-cigarette use increase so much in high school from 2017-2018?

We were also surprised at the percentage of students using any tobacco product in 2011, we thought it would be lower.

We also believe that if this survey was conducted in Canadian schools, the percentage of students using any tobacco product or e-cigarettes would be lower. This is due to the tobacco laws we have in Canada. Although we do believe that high school would still be higher than middle school.

name: Jessica Swanson
comment info:
In this graph I noticed that tobacco products in high schoolers were mostly constant until 2015 were it decreased and in 2017 increase rapidly to were the numbers in 2018 were even higher than the ones in 2014. E-cigs in high school also increased from from 2011, but the numbers did the same thing between 2015-2018 as tobacco products did. The decrease in numbers in 2015-2016 could have been the cause of laws: increasing the price of these products and increasing the age you have to be to buy them. 
     Overall tobacco products and e-cigs have remained constant in middle school. I believe the reason for this is because students who use tobacco products or e-cigs in middle school use them because it’s a new thing that people around them are trying and their curiosity gets the best of them. The use of tobacco and e-cigs in high schoolers are always greater and I believe this is because students have it more available to them from older friends, wanting more because they tried it in middle school or because of anxiety.
